title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Synthesis Research
 
We define synthesis as:

bringing together the results of multiple studies to test novel hypotheses


LTER is hypothesis driven




Means many disparate data are collected




Useful backdrop for innovative synthesis work!

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Working Groups & Synthesis
 

Since 2016, funded 14 full working groups (~4 meetings / 2 years)




In 2022, funded 4 SPARC groups (1 meeting + 1 year support)

Scientific Peers Advancing Research Collaboration





Proposals center around 1-3 synthesis hypotheses that use LTER data

Typically in addition to other datasets





Groups are immensely productive (often >5 publications / group)

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Grad Course & Working Groups
 

Early career researcher (ECR) demand for synthesis training far outstrips working group capacity




This course will help train ECRs in the quantitative and inclusive facilitation skills that are the hallmark of synthesis research




Course offerings are timed to leave students well prepared to apply for SPARC group funding

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion
 

The network has two primary justice goals heading into our next funding cycle:



Greater cultural, socioeconomic, and gender diversity throughout the LTER network




More rapid and innovative synthesis






This course is built–in part–to support these goals

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text: DEI Plan

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Course Goals
 

We have the following strategic goals for the course:



Surface and test new synthesis ideas for feasibility
Prepare more graduate students to be effective participants in/leaders of synthesis projects
Connect LTER graduate students across sites
Develop intergenerational linkages around synthesis research

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Course Structure
 

Course split into two major components

Instructional modules
Student-led synthesis projects


 


Module order reflects typical synthesis project evolution




More on projects shortly!

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Course Logistics
 

Course runs for 9 months (Sept - May)

Biweekly synchronous virtual meetings






First full week in-person at NCEAS

Facilitate cohort sense of community
Students form groups of 5-6 with interest in shared project idea







~30 students per cohort

~1 / LTER site

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Classes
 

Class meetings consist of inspiration and instruction

Inspiration = experienced synthesis scientist lends insight (60 min)
Instruction = work on topic of the week (120 min)





Instruction by: LNO staff, guest speakers, LTER Network-recruited mentors

Likely including other NCEAS folx!

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Module Categories
 


15 proposed modules from two categories





Team Science 

Team Science Practices
Inclusive Facilitation
Supporting Divergent, Emergent, and Convergent Thinking
Authorship & Intellectual Credit
Project Management
Logic Models
Communicating Findings


Quantitative Skills 

Reproducibility Best Practices
Version Control
Data Discovery & Management
Data Visualization and Exploration
Data Wrangling
Analysis & Modeling
Spatial Data & Interactivity
Reproducible Reports

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Team Science Emphasis
 

Synthesis work requires meaningful teamwork




Modules focus on these “soft skills”

Consistent inclusivity angle to modules in this category





Many of these skills are particularly absent from graduate school curricula

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Quantitative Emphasis
 

Synthesis work typically has significant data wrangling needs




Extensive harmonizing often pre-requisite to the most fundamental exploration




Quality control requires an in-depth examination of each primary project’s metadata

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Projects Overview
 

Students will work on projects outside of class sessions with their peers




Projects offer a real world context to apply the content covered in modules




Deliverables produced by project teams will be valuable entries in student portfolios

Dissertation/thesis chapters
Published papers
Data packages & software
Websites
SPARC group / working group / other grant application fodder

text:

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
‘Menu of Ideas’
 

Project ideas from all sources will be retained in a ‘menu of ideas’




Each LTER network synthesis activity will have the chance to add to this menu

Working groups / SPARC groups
Cohorts of SSECR students
All Scientists’ Meeting presentations





Subsequent cohorts of students can adopt and/or adapt ideas from this menu

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Project Mentors
 

Each project group will be paired with a discipline-relevant mentor with synthesis experience




Groups and mentors meet at least 5 times throughout the course




Content and structure of those meetings is up to those involved

Suggesting readings or collaborators
Discussing analytical approaches
Sharing prior and current experience

LTER Talks

title: Long Term Ecological Research
text:
Presentations given for LTER purposes are included below!


As part of the 2025-29 renewal proposal to the National Science Foundation the Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Network Office proposed an yearlong course to train early career researchers in synthesis work. Synthesis skills differ from primary research skills because synthesis requires a focus on collaboration as well as an increased emphasis on quantitative skills. Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers (SSECR) is that course and it will be first offered in fall of 2024 to a cohort of ~30 students (about 1 per LTER site). The course materials can be found at lter.github.io/ssecr though they will likely be under construction/revision until late 2024/early 2025.


Invited to give a presentation at National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at the monthly “roundtable” presentation.
